DIV1.P: LIFE'S VAGARIES, A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS. AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.

WRITTEN BY JOHN O'KEFFE, Author of Tony Lumpkin in Town; The Son in Law; The Dead Alive; Agreeable Surprize; Fontainbleau, or Our Way in France: The Positive Man; The Poor Soldier; Love in a Camp, or Patrick in Prussia; The Farmer; The Castle of Andalusia; The Young Quaker; Beggar on Horseback; Peeping Tom; The Prisoner at Large; The Toy, or Hampton Court Frolicks; Wild Oats, or The Strolling Gentleman; Little Hunchback; The Siege of Curzola; Modern Antiques, or The Merry Mourners; The Highland Reel; Birth Day, or Prince of Arragon; Sprigs of Laurel; The World in a Village; The London Hermit, or Rambles in Dorsetshire; The Irish Mimick, or Blunders at Brighton, &c. &c. &c.

Q.L: Improveable at will, in virtue lies,
It's tenure sure; it's income is divine.

DIV1.P: LONDON: PRINTED BY G. WOODFALL, FOR T. N. LONGMAN, PATERNOSTER-ROW. 1795.

LG.L: 'TIS strange that authors, who so rarely find
Their pray'rs can move an audience to be kind,
Still send, with piteous tone and look forlorn,
The Prologue forth to deprecate your scorn;
Such doleful heralds, which would fain appear
The timid struggles of a modest fear,
The surly Critic views with jealous spleen,
As the dull presage of the coming scene.
In vain, the dread hostility to calm,
E'en potent Flatt'ry tries her soothing balm;
Pity's a crime his losty soul disdains
And his pride feasts upon the poet's pains,
Yet now no critic rancour need we fear,
For lib'ral candour holds her empire here,
Candour, who scorns for little faults to pry,
But looks on merits with a partial eye.
And sure a bard whose muse so oft has found
The happy pow'r to kindle mirth around,
Though, in her sportive moods, averse to trace,
The rigid forms of Action, Time, and Place,
While gen'rous objects animate her view,
May still her gay luxuriant course pursue;
For, mid her whims, she still has shewn the art,
To press the USEFUL MORAL on the heart;
With just contempt the worthless to discard,
And deal to VIRTUE its deserv'd reward.
So aim'd the bard HORACE. (if haply we may dare,
Our humble scenes with noblest strains compare)
The bard whose favour'd muse could joy afford,
That eas'd the cares of Rome's Imperial Lord,
Who in her satire frolicksome and wild,
Gave vice the deepest wounds when most she smil'd.

DIV1.HEAD: PERSONS OF THE DRAMA.
DIV1.P: SCENE.—A Town, and adjacent Country near the Coast.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—A Parlour in DICKINS'S; Break∣fast things laid.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter SIR HANS BURGESS, and ROBIN.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR HANS.
SP.P: I'LL trust nothing to the errand cart, you must bring up my own waggon; cuts such a figure! a Gentleman's fine team ringing thro' a country town.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Why it does make folks stare.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: There's the Duke's cart, Lord, Mar∣quiss's cart, and why not his Worship's cart? and on it written in capitals, Sir Hans Bur∣gess! Samphire Hall. Go— [Exit Robin.] (Looks at his watch) Late breakfast here. This little shop-keeper is quite spoilt by a Lord's taking notice of him—aping all the absurd im∣pertinence of fashion; an insignificant cur mon∣grel, setting himself up for a greyhound.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter DICKINS, in a morning gown, &c. tying his neckcloth—sits.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: When one sups at the Castle, no rising next morning

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: The Castle! sup with Lord Viscount Torrendel.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: His Lordship would make me bumper it last night, roasting such bundles of his fine girls; 'pon my soul I and Torrendel knock'd the bot∣tle about rarely. How his Lordship stared at dinner when I hob nob'd him; says he, my dear Dickins, are you in earnest? 'pon my soul, said I, my dear Torrendel I am, that's poz. I'm used to good old black port, and his Lordship's pink Burgundy has given me an immense head-ach. No getring from him, he's such good company.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Then I'm not even to be asked to sit down?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Sir Hans Burgess! Oh, how do ye do?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Well, this is good, a Gentleman comes to talk about business, and its "Oh, how do ye do."

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Business! true, I ride out with my Lord this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Please, Sir, first to step into your shop, and weigh out the sugar and tobacco for my servant, Robin Hoofs.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick. (rising)
SP.P:
Sir, if you don't know how to behave as a parlour visitor to me, as a customer, walk into my shop, and wait there till you are serv'd. Here, John, take this person's orders. Weigh tobacco! as you are
now Sir Hans Burgess, I may yet be Sir An∣thony Dickens; I may be knighted for bring∣ing up an address. You made your money by a contract of hats, and an't I making mine by—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Your country merchant shop of all sorts.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: My banking-house, agencies, receiver∣ships, factorships—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: And coal-ships. Now I have laid out my money in buying a scope of land, and my grand hobby is to turn it into a fashionable sea∣bathing place. I have such a liberal mind to accommodate the publick, I built first there a beautiful house—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: For yourself. As my Lord says, to serve a man's self, has been long the way of doing things for the public good.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: I raised as pretty an hotel! and the neat row of lodging-houses!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: But to give it a name, you must get a few of us people of fashion down to it. Suppose I say to his Lordship, 'pon my soul Torrendel, now you should take a house from my friend, Sir Hans, he's a good, honest, stupid sort of a soul—why then, says my Lord, nay my dear Dickens, you are too severe. Yes, perhaps I may prevail on Torrendel to take one of your new houses.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Not so much good in you, hem! a pity, friend Dickens, my Lord can't admit you for an hour to his table, but it makes you so cursed saucy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Proud! a proof my Lord ca'n't do without me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Why you are so clever that I will trust you, because I ca'n't do without you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Very civil, (bows) as my Lud says; then says I, oh, dem it my Lud—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Devils in you, and the Lud; I came to consult you. You know I design to bestow my ward Augusta Woodbine, with her whole fortune, on my son George; but I fear the re∣port of her riches will bring all your flashy, high-titled gentry about her, then—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Ay! then, indeed, she may be for despising a son of yours. As my Lud was fil∣ling his glass, my jogging his elbow, dem it, Dickens, said he, you are sull of mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Oh, zounds!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Hem! wa'n't Miss Augusta adopted by her uncle on his discarding his own daughter for a faux pas with some man of fashion two and twenty years back?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Devil's in your twenty years back! how to bring my son's marriage about now?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Make your ward think that her uncle has made a second will, and that she's not worth two-pence, then she'll be glad to snap at your George.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Eh! I expect her to-day from Lon∣don. According to that plan, it will shew too much attention to go myself to meet her—I'll let her down—I'll send any body—will you go, my dear fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P:
Civil again; (bows) its a doubt to me, if you know how to make a bow, Sir Hans, ha, ha, ha! this morning I, making my bow of leave to his Ludship, sliding back, stumbled upon the poor Chaplain's toe; my Lud laughed!
Zounds! cries his Reverence, you've killed me! Huzza, says my Lud, then the parson's dead, and has lost his living, ha, ha, ha! Oh, but to meet this Lady I'll send my daughter Fanny. Here she is.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter FANNY, stops short, and makes a low curtesy.
DIV3.P: Why, Miss, isn't this your school hour?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, papa, but I've stept home for a book; did you see my Pleasing Instructor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: My dear, you must step over to the inn to receive—

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Lord! papa, what would our Go∣verness say if a young Lady of her school was seen going into an inn? besides its now my reading time; then I have my embroidery; then I must practice my musick; then say my French lesson; then the dancing-master; then, papa—

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: I must not take her from her accom∣plishments—I'll go, and in my way drop this parcel at my Lud's, a trivial thing, but was I to send it, it would be, Eh, now, Dickens, why didn't you come yourself, my dear fel∣low? always happy to see you. Must call, my Lord may think I'm getring proud, pride is so contemptible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: So it is, I despise it at this mo∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Well, good bye.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Devil's in your good bye! Introduce me now to Lord Torrendel.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P:
Why, I don't know, his Lordship sup∣ports
vast dignity; but never mind, tho' he is very difficult of access, I'll introduce you, for my Lud says, Dickens, I'll be glad to see some of your people; from my respect to you, you may command any service—never mind their aukward want of breeding, if known to you. Sir Hans, I'll present you to my Lud; expect to see all the importance of genuine old nobility; yet I'm of that conse∣quence with him, that once presented by me, his Lordship and you are hand and glove.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Ay! that you and I may be hand and purse.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—A Chamber in LORD TORREN∣DEL'S Castle.
DIV3.STAGE: Lnter LORD TORRENDEL, and L'OEILLET, adjusting his dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Then you think, L'Oeillet, Lady Torrendel is still in Cumberland. She is too good a wife—I use her ill.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Oui! mais, mi Lor, dat be de faute of la nature, vich did give your Lorship constitution galante amoureuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: No interruption from my wife here, ha, ha, ha! good deception this of mine, to make her believe I'm at Lisbon for the re∣establishment of my health; never was better in my life!

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Your Lorship be robuste comme Hercule; vid your spindle shank.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Lady Torrendel, among the lakes, little imagines that I am retir'd hither to this scene of darling pleasures; a doubt to me if she even knows I've still a seat in this part of the country. She is truly amiable, her mind stored with every delicate refinement, and for per∣sonal charms has few superiors; I like people should know so fine a woman chose me;—yes, she seems the only person unconscious of her shining qualities; but I cannot help my irre∣sistible penchant for variety, (ringing without) I'm not at home; the little girl, Dickins's daughter Fanny! isn't her name Fanny? an absolute Cherub!

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Ah! oui milor—Fanny Dickins, Fanny Cherub!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: But living beauty cannot banish the sweet remembrance of Emily Woodbine. If her father hadn't disinherited her for coming off with me, and adopted his niece, I shou'dn't now be troubled with this profligate boy of her's, this Lord Arthur, as he calls himself— presumes as if my son in real wedlock. My fitting him out for the Indies was doing very handsome for a chance child.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Milor, I did vid money, you give me, furnish him superbement for voyage de mer; but he did make such a sabat affreux in de ship, dat he vas turn'd out— (aside) so I did tell you; but your money I have snug dans ma poche.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: He's well enough, I hear, as to his person.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Oui! il est fait á peindre, l'image of your lorship!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: But mad! I'm absolutely afraid of him.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Milor, here come de pretty girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: L'Oeillet! how do I look this morning? candid now! I always like the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Den, en enverité, milor, you look not above fifty, tho' you are a quarter past.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Fifty! L'Oeillet you are exceed∣ingly coarse.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: 'Pon my word, Sir, my Lord I mean, if you talk that way to me, I won't come here any more; I didn't know you was in the room, or I shou'dn't have come in I assure you, Sir, my Lord I mean.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Ah, petite badine. Mamselle Fanny come purpose to see my Lor.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Monsieur, how can you tell such fibs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Do now, my love, declare and make me happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Then I only came because—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: What, my love?

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Ah, pourquoi?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Because papa says its a boyish play, and all the rooms in our house are so small, and you've such a fine long gallery here, and Jenny the house-keeper's daughter is so smart at—he! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet. (snatching it,)
SP.P: Va tén!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor. (breaks it open.)
SP.P: Oh, some beg∣ging petition. How! my Lady Torrendel's hand! L'Oeillet do you read, and write some consistent answers; date the letters from Lisbon as usual.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Wile you, milor, play de raquette vid Miss Fanny.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: What! can you play, Sir, my Lord I mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor. (aside).
SP.P: To win a girl one must comply with all her childish follies. (To L'OEil∣let) Say the sprain's not better—can't lift my arm—and all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Ca'n't lift you arm! you flourish it finely, Sir; my Lord I mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Come, my love.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Ah! bien—trés bien!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter DICKINS, and SIR HANS, who stand amazed.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Oh! my Lord, what a rare old beau the King wou'd think you now, and if my papa was to see me—oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: So, this is your "Pleasing In∣structor".

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: The dignity of "genuine old no∣bility!"

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Ah, hem! what, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: I beg you Lordship's pardon, but I brought a parcel, and am come up to save your Lordship's coming down.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Impudent intrusion this!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Miss, you step over to the Rose Inn to receive a young Lady just arrived from Lon∣don—go.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Lord, Papa!—give my battledores to Jenny.
SP.STAGE: (apart to Lord Torrendel; goes to door, turns, makes a low courtesy, and exit gravely)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: How finely she holds up her head.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: All the good she's got at the board∣ing school.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Dem it! once you make free with these kind of people.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: The devil's in your strutting! why don't you present me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Oh, true, my Lord give me leave to introduce—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Ah! hey! L'Oeillet!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Dickins, since I have been intro∣duced by you, his Lordship and I are hand and glove, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Get drunk with a man over night, and in the morning its—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Ah! hey! L'Oeillet!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Stop, my Lord ca'n't do with∣out you.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Mon dieu! vere be my Lord to rell him of dis beauty lady stop at de Rose Inn?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: I see the valet's the prime favourite after all. (aside) Monsieur, please to accept—

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Qu'est que c'est? vat's dis?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: 'Tis—you are so civil.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Ah! je vous entends—to make me civil.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Two guinea! very polite! he vant ma protection. In his Lordship's service I have been but four year, yet have sav'd two thousand guinea; the guinea flow to my coffer in many channel. My Lor fancy watch, trinket to present as de∣coy to Lady, I buy at ten guinea, charge him twenty. I wink at de tradesman's bill, ven paid he slip me de guinea:—if tenant want lease re∣newed, I speak to my Lor, tenant mé donne the guinea. De maitre tink we be dere ser∣vants, but when we have got into de love-secret, pardi! den de maitre become servant to de valet de chambre.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—A Room in an Inn.

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: This way, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: How d'ye do, Ma'am, after your journey?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Tolerably well, Miss—but, pray, who am I to thank for this obliging enquiry?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Why, Miss, a'n't you the great heiress, Miss Augusta Woodbine, Sir Hans Burgess expected down here from London?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Where is the good old gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: He good! brought papa upon me just how! he, he, he! I was caught—but pray don't you young Ladies in London sometimes play at shuttlecock?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! why, Miss, you are very agreeable—what a simple thing! (aside) but, how came you to know, or expect me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Papa sent me to receive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: I didn't know Sir Hans had a daughter—Miss Burgess I presume.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: He, he, he! no! no! I am not Miss, but I may be Mrs. Burgess, for young George is quite partial to me; there he's now gone on his travels round Brighton, and Battle, and Hastings, Sandwich, and Margate, and Rams∣gate. My dear soul, George Burgess is a very fine creature, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: I ca'n't doubt his taste, Miss, when I understand he's an admirer of your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Ah! now I see the difference between you and us down here. You are a true Lady, and we are only conceited figures, and so I'll tell all the Ladies in our school, and I don't care if my French teacher hears me too. 'Pon my honour, with all my finery, I'm but a shabby genteel.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: If my scheme of letting down our young heiress, can bring about a match with Sir Hans's son George, by agreement I touch the handsome present.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: La, papa! why don't you speak to the young Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Welcome, Miss!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sir. (courtesies) I wish somebody would call my servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Miss, I'll run.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Stop. Now to let her down. (aside) Miss, I've discharged your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: How, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: And, my dear, instead of attendance on yourself, you must learn to attend on others, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sir! very odd and mysterious; this brutal treatment— (aside)—my guardian lives but a few miles—the carriage ready!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Never mind, my dear, you'll be able to walk as far as you've to go; you can walk!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Heavens! what can be the mean∣ing!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: A word, Miss; you have been brought up with the idea of a great fortune. Smoke! your uncle has made a second will, and bequeath'd all his property to a—some Mr. Jackson, or Mr. Johnson, no matter who.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: I don't know who you are, Sir, but if acquainted in my affairs, surely by my uncle's will I am—

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: A man's last will is the clincher, tho' he had made fifty before; you are left a trifling legacy, and a handsome education, so must now battle it out for yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: I could cry for her misfortune, if I wasn't glad at its making us more equal. Be∣fore, I admir'd; but now, I shall love her dearly.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: My generosity is such, that at Sir Hans's request, I'll take you into my house to be governess to my daughter Fanny, here.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Can this be possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Lawk! then I'm to leave school!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: You shall have my protection, you may dine at my table when we have no parti∣cular company. No occasion to acquaint you, my dear, of my property and fortune—first fashion. (looks at his watch) My Lord may now have call'd at my house! but dem-it, let him call again!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter JOHN, with a large bag.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Here, Sir Hans's man says you sold him better moist sugar for 6d. a pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Get you gone, you rascal!

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: La, papa, why don't you mind the business of the shop?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Hem! yes, I want a governess for my daughter. What say you, Miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sir, I am a friendless orphan; no alternative—but such an asylum!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Come, young Lady, don't be cast down.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P:
I am surprised—perhaps concern'd; but the prospect of riches gave me little plea∣sure in the reflection that I was to possess what belong'd to an unfortunate relative; the unfor∣giving spirit of her obdurate parent took the birth-right from his own lamented daughter, cast down! I could be happy was I sure my uncle's wealth would devolve on the offspring of his child's offence; the poor youth, who may at this moment be a wretched outcast,
disown'd by an unprincipled father, and no in∣heritance, but his mother's shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Why, a babe was, I heard, the con∣sequence of your Cousin's slip; a boy—this young mand Lord Arthur D'Aumerle, as he calls himself; (aside) but, dear, nobody knows any thing of the bantling; it may be dead or drowned, or—well, but, Miss, what think ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sir, I accept your offer.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Now, I shall have you under my own eye, no more playing shuttlecocks with Lords— but, how are you qualified for this office? what is your idea of the duties, in bringing up a young woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sir, by the mouth of a parent she receives admonition from Heaven itself; and when he commits that charge to another, it is indeed sacred. The care of youth is an ardu∣ous, and delicate trust of confidence, and honor; I look upon truth, cleanliness, and frugality, to be the first principles in a lady's education. They preserve to her mind, person, and means, purity, health, and independence of obligation, which thro' the devious paths of her future life, to the unsuspecting female, is often the con∣cealed adder, for the destruction of her in∣nocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: She set out pretty well about my heavenly authority, and my delicate mouth; but, lord, she has got quite out; (aside) well, in truth, my dear, your quondam guar∣dian, bid me break this affair in a rough way, to lower your spirit, to your situation; but it's my intention to treat you with kindness and respect. (aside) This will do me no harm, when she finds she has still the fortune

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Vraiment oui! here is de char∣mante inconnue for milor; (aside) and Miss Fanny! ah! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: And Miss Fanny's pa! pa! (inter∣posing) Monsieur—you want now, I suppose, to engage my daughter in a match of cricket; but you shall get all the notches on your pate.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Non! Monsieur, I did come vid milor's compliments—you ride cavalcade vid him dis morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: What! after his affronting me!

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Affront pah! votre interêt.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: True! interest is the gold-beater's leaf, for my wounded pride. Come, Miss, be chearful; you'll dine with us—dinner on table at six.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Why, papa, we always dine at one.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Fanny, to amuse you, will show you our town here.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: I vill show de Lady de town.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins. (Bowing)
SP.P: Don't you believe it. After you, s'il vous plait, Monsieur.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, papa, I'll take Miss Augusta to the cathedral, the play-house, and shambles, the beast-market, and assembly-room, and by— she shall see the fine gallery of pictures, in my Lord's castle too.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin. (Without)
SP.P: Give me my own big bottle of old claret, in my own fist.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: A man! oh! Lord! I must take care of my governess.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter TIMOLIN, with wine and glass, and Land∣lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Puppies! but they coudn't read in my face, that I was gentleman to a Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: Here, porters, fetch up his Lord∣ship's, and the Gentleman's trunks, let Dick and Tom Ostler give a help; take care how you turn the stairs.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter WAITER, with two small bundles.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Here, Ma'am, is the luggage.

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: And call for claret! (aside) Your master, Sir, is—?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: The Honorable Lord Arthur D' Aumerle.

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: The Honorable Lord—

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin. (taking papers out of his pocket).
SP.P: I hope my Lord wo'n't find out, that I collected all these tradesman's bills, which he ran up in London; he'd never have thought of them him∣self. This claret is neat—since he did call for it, I may as well drink it; for he has run out of the house. If his father, this Lord Torrendel wo'n't do something, no going back to London, for us!

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Sir, the other gentleman is calling for you, and making a great noise.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Noise! aye, that's quite himself. Then, Sir, this gentleman will wait on that gen∣tleman, and that may happen to save all the bottles and glasses in your house.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: He has just taken lodgings, at the jeweller's over the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: What may the price be?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: I think, they let them at three guineas a week.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin. (Whistles, Waiter stares)
SP.P: Don't be frighten'd, it's only a little new tune I was humming.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Sir, he desires his luggage to be brought to him. (Timolin ashamed, looking at bundles, whistles) Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: What's the matter with you now? luggage! have you good strong porters here, and a big cart?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: For what, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: For—hem! only Sir—I'm afraid, our luggage will break down the landlady's stair-case. "And there was three travellers— travellers three."

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. Before the Castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: No, the phaeton: (calling off) I may see this little girl in the evening, and after an hour on horseback; my limbs, not quite so sup∣ple, appear rather older than such a young crea∣ture should think one; but, true—I asked this Dickins to ride out with me to-day. One should hold these sort of people at arm's length, till we want to turn them into some use.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter TIMOLIN, who takes papers from his pocket, and thrusts them into Lord TORREN∣DEL'S hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: There! now you have the whole kit of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Who are you? what's all this? bills!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Yes, and by my soul they're not bank bills, and that's the worst of them; and, they're not play bills, and that's the best of them; for there's not a gaming debt in the whole cluster.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: But, friend, you should have de∣livered them to my banker, Mr. Dickins.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: A banker! he'll give me the money! (joy) by finding you so good, oh! how you've disappoined me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Stop! (looks-at bills) "Lord Torrendel, debtor, for goods delivered to Lord Arthur;" who the Devil's Lord Arthur D'Au∣merle?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Now don't be in a passion, why, I am his servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: But who is he himself?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Come, be aisy my Lord, don't go to pretend to know nothing of your own child.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: How dare any fellow assume Lord Arthur!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: He has the honor of being your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: 'Tis false.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Well, he has no honor in being your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: An infernal rascal! run about, contract debts, send in his bills to me! I won't pay a shilling to save him from perdi∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Perdition! some new-fashion'd name for the King's Bench.

SP.SPEAKER: Groom.
SP.P: My Lord, am I to saddle the ches∣nut mare for Mr. Dickins? he insists upon hav∣ing it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Yes, yes, scoundrel!

SP.SPEAKER: Groom.
SP.P: She cost your Lordship two hundred guineas; he's a bad rider, and if she should get any hurt—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Dem it, don't trouble me with your quarrels.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P:
Refuse his child a few pounds, a bit
of beef, a feather bed, and a hat and a pair of shoes, or so; yet mounts a Mr. Dickins on a horse cost 200 guineas!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: This damn'd—, can't keep within the allowance that I—

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: What allowance do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: An extravagant—

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: He is extravagant; wicked; he's a devil! but, it's all your fault, my Lord, as a father; not noticing and bringing him up with a sense of duty to himself and his neighbours. Call to mind how you loved his mother, and inveigled her from her friends, tho' you wasn't married to the poor unhappy lady, that doesn't make the child's little finger a bit less your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Emily! (takes out his purse) for her dear sake—

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Then blessings on you! besides, Lord Arthur is such a gay—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Lord Arthur again! not a guinea!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: And as like your lordship as a sprightly young buck is like—an auld sham∣bling baboon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: I know nothing about him.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: These they call gallantries, to bring a living creature into the world and then to leave him like a wild beast to prey upon society. (Lord Torrendel walks about enraged; Timolin following.) Now, my lord, only see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Begone.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P:
I'll tell you what—you'll drive him desp'rate; he'll do some hellish thing or other; he'll commit a suicide upon either himself or me, for, when once he thinks any thing, he
immediately does it, without thinking at all about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Harkye, you scoundrel! if I hear of your lord Arthur, or yourself, being seen about my door, I'll have you taken up.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Well, a small man taken up, doesn't cut such a pitiful figure, as a great man taken down.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: This eternal torment!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter DICKINS, dressed in a uniform of Hunt, and JOHN.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Yes, John, I think I'm very well equipp'd to ride out with my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Well, sir, you had a hundred guineas fee with me, and the day may yet come, for my crossing a hunter.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P:
It may, John; when I was 'prentice in Barbican, and, like the house dog, slept in the shop; promis'd the watchman a pint, to rouse me, to go to the Easter Epping Hunt; "five o'clock and a fine morning!" thump comes the pole against the shop door; tingle, tingle, goes the little bell behind it; up starts me, from my bed under the counter; on with my buckskin and jemmy jacket; jumps into my two boots; mounts my three and sixpenny nag; but, first I put my spurs in my pocket; hey off we go, thro' Hackney, Hammerton—I saw the stag once, but then heard the hounds all the way; find I've a short and a long stirrup: dis∣mount to put them even; forgetting to buckle the girt, down comes me, and the saddle at top of me; by this I was slung out; but, to prove
I was in at the death, presents my kind mistress with a piece of the stag's horn, which horn she gives her husband for a tobacco stopper, with "ah my dear hubby, I wish you were as good a sportsman as your 'prentice Tony Dickins, ah he's the smart fellow," ha! ha! ha! and so I was, and dem it so I am still—John, you needn't wait dinner, I shall dine with Torrendel. Exit John. Sir Hans! curse it, I can't be plagued with such a silly old fool now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Hollo, Dickins! so you have seen my ward, Miss Augusta.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I have humbled her rarely, but pray don't delay me now, I'm engaged to ride out with my Lord. I, and Torrendel, may first take a turn or two down the Street, arm in arm, right side, so don't hide the star! my dear Hans don't stop to talk to me; if you've people with you, and should bow, I'll return it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Scoundrel! call himself my son; keep servants too.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Well, my Lord, here I am: whip and spur.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Desire the porter not to admit either of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Not admit either of us!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P:
Poh! hold your tongue. (pushing him) My lud, I had a little head ache from our
debauch last night; you look vastly well, but a little cherry will do us both good.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, what are you talking about?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Why, my Lord, you sent for me to—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Poh! poh! man, I sha'n't ride out to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Go to the expence of dressing! view'd by every body in the town, strutting out in my leathers, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Why, Sir, you're equipp'd in your leathers.

P.Q: Poh! poh! man I sha'n't ride out to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: And, pray, man, who cares whe∣ther you ride or walk? big little nobody! I'll introduce myself—Gad's curse! a'n't I a Knight, and if I can effect this marriage with Augusta and my George—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur. (Without)
SP.P: Timolin! (Enters in slippers) (to Sir Hans.) Where's Timolin? Sir, I ask pardon. My rascal dare loiter and had only to come and bring me a couple of hundred guineas from my father; I'll see my Lord my∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Some young fellow of fashion!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: I'm run out in slippers; all asleep here!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, they were at a jollifica∣tion last night; Mr. Dickins told me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Who? aye, my father keeps it up here, and I without the price of a bottle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans. (aside)
SP.P: A little civility might make this Gentleman take lodgings at Samphire-hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: So, I'm not to be let in! then I'll have some of you out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Are you in this way, Sir! (offering snuff-box, which Lord Arthur dashes through a window.) the devil's in you, Sir! what sort of mad trick's that, to knock a Gentleman's snuff-box.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Whose boots are these? what do you ask for these boots?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: They are bought already, Sir, I'm bringing them home to my Lord Torrendel.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: My father; (aside) you could make me a pair?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Certainly, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: These are about my size.
SP.STAGE: (kicks slippers off, and puts the boots on.)

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Don't put them on, Sir, I can take your measure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: My dear fellow, why should I give you that trouble, when here is a pair ready made? that fits, now this, the whole world is made up of this, that, and tother, I have this, and that, and tother I don't want, for two boots will do for me as well as fifty.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, don't walk about in them, his Lordship wo'n't have them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: A paradox! his Lordship cannot have them, and his Lordship has them already.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Only the pebble knocked out of the lid! never saw such a strange—

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: The boots are now unsaleable, his Lordship wo'n't take them off my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Nor off my lordship's feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Lord! then I'll pocket my broken box.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: They are two guineas, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur. (To Sir Hans)
SP.P: Sir, I beg you a thousand pardons for my inadvertency.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Inadvertency! a man of rank, by not knowing what he does.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: We never book such trifles, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Well then set them down to me, to Lord Arthur D'Aumerle; or, carry the bill to my father; or, Timolin will pay you; or, any body will pay you.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: I'll see if the law wo'n't make you pay me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Sir, I presume you are Lord Arthur D'Aumerle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Right—who are you? (aside) oh! Sir Hans Burgess! that old fool they were laughing at—I hear an immense character of you, Sir Hans.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Pray, my Lord, what do they say of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! what I ca'n't say to your face: that's my father's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Indeed! why we didn't know Lord Torrendel had a son.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: He doesn't like my coming about him—he affects to be thought so very young, to recommend him to the Ladies; you understand me, Sir Hans?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Not see you! he's a very unnatu∣ral father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: And yet I'm quite a natural son.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Sir, my Lord is very much alarm'd, and begs you will not commit any more outrage, or attempt to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Did he give the money to my servant?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Why, Sir, I did see his Lordship's purse—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Then, he has my profound duty—I ask his pardon. (exit Thomas) He's a very tolerable father after all—huzza! I'll now pay my debts and be a man again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: I with my son George had your fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: You've a son? I'll shew him how to knock your cash about!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Good morning to you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Not so, Sir Hans! come and take a Sandwich with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: You hit my humour—I'm very wise and cunning—I'd do any thing to get money: but all only to see my son George make a blaze.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: A conflagration! come—old Hock's the word. I have a bachelor's house— that is, I lodge at the jeweller's yonder; I like to have things about me; I've ordered in wines and relishes—I want your opinion of a horse I've bought just now. Dam me! how I'll curve it before noble dad's door! he shall see I can spend my money like a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: What a noble lad, I could never get my son George to buy a jack-ass.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Come, old hock's the word.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. LORD ARTHUR'S lodgings. New cloaths, linen, saddle, hat, &c. lying on chairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Oh, melancholy is our new home here. I'd wish to keep up my poor master's spirits, but he'll see an empty pocket in my dismal countenance. If his papa had only given him as much as would have taken us back to London—well, well, we have no debts to lay hold on us in this town, however— (sees the things) oh thunder and zounds! what's here;— been shopping on the strength of the expected money! Ordered in wine too! Oh, oh, then not a cork shall be drawn till it is paid for.
SP.STAGE: (Locks the cupboard and takes the key.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur. (without)
SP.P: This way, Sir Hans. Oh, very well ma'am; but where's my ser∣vant?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Bringing company too!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter LORD ARTHUR, and SIR HANS.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, walk in—be seated. So we've touched.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Yes! we shall be touched.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Timolin, that old hock!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Timolin, that old hock! I believe you're jumping out of your leather.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P:
Ha! ha! ha! very well, Ti∣molin. Sir Hans, that fellow's a treasure: but, when he does any thing clever, such as bringing
a man a couple of hundred guineas, it makes him so pert—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Yes! my Lord, when once a ser∣vant knows he's an honest man, he begins to be an impudent rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Poh! what talk's that! Was the devil busy with you, Sir, to send in all these new things from the tradesmen?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! very well— Timolin, the wine!—unlock! No! Sir Hans, this is the secret history of old hock, (pointing to the cupboard) and this (touching his leg) is the key to it.
SP.STAGE: (Bursts the door, and brings out wine.)

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Broke open the cupboard—Oh, he'll get us both hanged.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Sir Hans, without expedient a man's nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: You and your servant, my Lord, put one in mind of a couple of ghosts. You are all spirit, and he is no body—ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Bravo!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: My Lord, let me send these things back to the honest people.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Send yourself out of the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Only hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: I'll give you such a beating, you villain!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Well, so you do but hear me, beat me as long as you like.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Lay the money upon my bureau and go to the devil. (Puts him out) The fel∣low is so puffed with doing a petty service—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P:
My Lord, I hope for the honour of seeing you down at Samphire Hall, an infant
scheme merely for the health and convenience of the gentry in this part of the country. I've converted a naked beech into as commodious a sea-bathing place—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Then your principal object is—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: The main ocean!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Psha! you want to establish it into a fashion? its done, I'll be seen there upon your stein or esplanade; my physician shall re∣commend all his patients from Brompton, and Paddington; a variety of gambling tabbies, honourable black legs, and rickety children.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: You told him! then untell him; for he won't hear me talk at all at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: There again! then, dam'me! now you shall bring me some brawn and an∣chovies.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Now don't make quite a kiskawn of yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Sir, I thought, when I told you that my Lord's purse—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Yes! I'm grateful for good news—you shall have a bottle. (gives him one and places him at table. Timolin stares, then runs to take it from him). What! don't be quite so busy; sit still.— (to Thomas) You march.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: What a fine model for my son George! Come, my Lord, I'll give you a patriotic toast—Here's success to all my un∣dertakings.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Patriotic and disinterested in∣deed, Sir Hans! here's—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Success to my undertakings!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Right, little pigeon—finish your bottle by yourself, and, if you quarrel with your company, I'll kick you both out of the room. Have you advertised this place at Samphire Hall?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: I fancy advertising might make it better known; for newspapers are a sort of thing that's read.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Why, yes, Sir Hans, people do read newspapers; how the deuce did you find out that? Come, I'll draw you up a flourish∣ing advertisement.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: I employed a famous auctioneer to draw up one for me. (takes a paper and peruses) Mind how he describes the beauties— To the right, the bold cliffs and high bluff heads —at the foot, Sir Hans has built an elegant strait row of houses, called the Crescent— Eh! that's very foolish.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Why, yes! your crescent is a little in the full moon order, ha! ha! ha!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter TIMOLIN, walks about with his arms folded.
DIV3.P: What do you mean by walking in here with your executioner's face?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Well, I didn't run in debt for my face. Step in here, all of you.

SP.SPEAKER: First Man.
SP.P: Sir, the horse you bought—I'll be satisfied with a draught on Mr. Dickins, our banker, for the 50 guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: Second Man.
SP.P: Neighbours, you can take back your goods undamaged: but, I insist on being paid for my boots.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Timolin!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Oh! I know nothing at all about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Pay the people this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: With what?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: What! the two hundred my father gave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: He didn't give me a Manx rap half∣penny.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: No! why, I thought—by Heavens! I'll get into the house myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans. (rising)
SP.P: Oh! my Lord, a thought strikes me of great consequence, in the present case.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Well—Sir—quick?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: That here, instead of curlews, he should have said sea-gulls.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Damn your sea-gulls, Sir! see a nobleman baited, by a parcel of mecha∣nical—

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: There's all your goods for you again—what more do you want?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Every one of you, lay down my property this moment, in the very spot from whence you took it. I'll pay you the first money I receive; but now, begone, or I'll murder you.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Go good people, whatever he says he'll do.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Here's gaiety and innocence!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: True, it was you who told me first, that the money—I'll make you gay, you innocent dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Oh! what a model for my George.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—A Gallery in Lord Torrendel's hung with whole length Pictures of Women.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: So very lovely!

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Une beauté celeste! et pauvre— poor, derfore no danger from relations. So, my Lord, think no more of the rich mechanic Dickins's daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Why, their sturdy Citizens may be troublesome; but you say this young Lady is coming with Fanny, to see my pictures.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Oui, my Lor.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: This way, Miss Augusta.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: L'Oeillet! (winks, exit L'Oeillet) well, you have brought your new friend, to see my paintings?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Oh yes, Sir; my Lord I mean, but I didn't think you'd be in the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Don't let her be alarmed at my prsence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Oh true, I'm not to let out you are a Lord? but she don't mind Lords, she's come from London; why, there's plenty of such stupid nonsense.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Fanny! I should like to have your picture here.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: No, my Lord, sure you woudn't?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: And you shall have mine for a locket.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: You think me a silly girl, but I know enough, never to give tokens, or accept presents, but from my papa, and one besides, a certain— not an old Lord! but a young man. As my new song says,

LG.L: Lasses all are simple,
So the wise ones say:
Caught by blush or dimple,
Who is silly pray?
The ribband, and the star,
One smile brings on a par,
With rustic maid, in her stockings blue:
Squeezing the hand, is the lasses cue.
For ting, ting, ting, ting.
I can dance, and sing.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: When the boy we fancy,
Jolly comes to woo:
Lady gay or Nancy,
All know what to do.
Tho' mantling cheek denies,
And language of the eyes,
When the tongue gives you words unkind,
Take in her silence the lasses mind.
With our ting, ting, ting'
I can dance, and sing.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Here, my Lord, be de beauté Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: What a monkey you are, I don't know what you mean, by making so much of my governess.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Oh, are you here Fanny, the pictures in that room are so fascinating.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: L'Oeillet has good taste, she's a lovely creature; (bows) servant ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Miss! never mind this old gentleman, he's only the house steward.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Old!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta. (looking round)
SP.P: Something in the manner of the beauties at Hampton Court— true, I've been told what he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: What do they say of my Lord? he, he, he! she's going to abuse you.

SP.SPEAKER: Auguste.
SP.P: Fancy habits, or drawn in their real characters?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Both, madam, they are Ladies that his Lordship's heart has at times been devoted to.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: And his Lordship, I presume, has flattered himself into the idea, that he was at times in possession of their hearts.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Now, what do you bow for? Miss wasn't speaking of you, Mr. Old Steward.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: I was told he's very vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes! he's quite a conceited figure, and as grey as a badger—isn't he, Mr. Old Steward? (apart) I said she'd abuse you.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: What a sweet expression in that coun∣tenance!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Her loss, madam, makes a chasm in his Lordship's heart, never to be filled but by a face, the lovely emblem of this collected group of charms. (bows to her) That is Miss Emily Woodbine.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: My cousin! then am I in the house of her base destroyer!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: What's the matter Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Not much, Sir, I'm not very well. Come, Fanny! a star! heavens! have I been talking to—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Stay, my divine girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: My Lord, it ill becomes my youth, and humble life, to offer admonition, where age should be the monitor of inexperience; and exalted rank only illustrious in virtuous example. The veil of delicacy drops between my mind and tongue—I cannot say what I think you: but the bitter reproach will yet reach your heart, when your only hope lies in pardon for a bad life, from perhaps, a too late repentance.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: What, has my governess run away! why Miss! Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P:
Her words have piere'd me—but I must have her—the only being worthy to sup∣ply the place of my lose Fanily, and banish all other pursuits from my mind; from her good
sense I shall enjoy rational society—and from her beauty—yes, L'Oeillet must finish, what he has so well begun.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Prevent a dutiful son from seeing his honour'd parent! I'll convince him I'm a good boy—he shall see me, and I will be his comfort, and, though he commands me to be gone, I'll stay with him to prove my obedi∣ence. What a pity that the omission of saying a few words, before I was born, should prevent me from being lawful heir to this castle! perhaps the pride of my father! the darling of the tenants! favourite of the neighbours, and friend to the poor! now, a wretched outcast, shunned like a savage, foe to mankind, and man at enmity with me! no establishment! profession! friend, or character. Oh! my father, where are you? (looks round with grief) do not shun, I'll kneel, till you spurn me from you—that face! it is my mother. I heard of his Lordship's gallery of beauties—quite an exhibition for every starer: but my dear mother shall no more be dishonoured, by making one in this un∣happy collection—no, by heavens! her misfor∣tunes shall be no longer the topic, for the sneer∣ing comments of vulgarity and ill nature. (lifts the picture down) Timolin! why don't you come up? Timolin!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: What uproar is this in my house?

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P:
Sacristie! by dis meeting milor
will find out, I did keep all de money, he did give me for his son's support.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Have you any business with me, Sir? who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur. (falls on his knee, and points to picture)
SP.P: Sir, this was my mother.
SP.STAGE: (Lord Tor∣rendel looks at both, puts his handkerchief to his eyes)

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Diantre! he is softened, and I am ruined—milor, here be Miss Augusta in de hall still.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Begone! (pushes him off angrily, walks slowly and then turns) My son, the child of Emily!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: This our first interview since my infancy! my father not speak to me! no gentle word, no complacent smile. Now I am poor! where to turn? every face meets me with a frown, a sea of horrors rush on me! the storm's up, and let it blow me as it will!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Well, and you saw your papa?

SP.SPEAKER: Arthur.
SP.P: My heart was good, but now I'm all vexation, grief, and terror. A look now and then at this, might calm my mind. Timolin, take that picture to my lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Arthur.
SP.P: Take that picture to my lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Cram a fine dashing fellow into their prisons for hats and shoe-buckles! Sha'n't. What a bright model this Arthur for my son George! yet if he had but life and soul to shew it, George is a compleat and finish'd pattern for most of our young men now-a-days. I don't know any one thing that my boy is not perfect master of, music, dancing, fencing, lan∣guages, a magazine of accomplishments: set him to country sports, he excels every body; he's as keen as an attorney, has the courage of a mastiff, generous as the Man of Ross! but hang it, all his shining qualities clouded by want of spirit to dash! Oh, if I could but see him a bold, free dasher!

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Sir, who should pass me just now but the young squire.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: What, my son George whisk'd by you in a phaeton? a chaise and four? a tandem?
George, why, what the devil's this sort of figure?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir, how are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Plague on it! spare no expence for you to appear like a prince; give you mo∣ney to flash in a shining tour, to be here and there, before any body can tell where you are, and when I expected you to come, tearing up the pavement, in a phaeton as high as the clouds, over chickens, old women, and pigs, all the people jumping out of the way, with huzza for the young Squire, here you sneak into town, limp∣ing like a lame beggar-man, covered with dust as if you had been dancing in a cannister of Scotch snuff. 'Sblood, Sir! what do you mean by this behaviour?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir, on my leaving home you gave me a two hundred pound note, and six guineas; there's your note—I've still one pound five and seven-pence in bank.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Devil's in you and your seven∣pence! I wish you were both in the stocks you pitiful cur. Damn me if I havn't a mind to disinherit you, and adopt Robin. Robin you can drive six?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: You knows, Sir, I drives eight in our waggon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Psha! go to the Rose inn, and be∣speak the best dinner they can provide for I and George, and the gallant Arthur, if we can find him.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Why, Sir, I am a little hungry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: By the Lord! a son of mine knaw∣ing a crust in the open street!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir, as I paid for it at the last ale∣house where I supp'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Supp'd at an alehouse!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, a neat little place, sign of the Goat in Boots.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Oh, Lord! and perhaps some of my friends, in their coaches, saw you?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, Lady Beechgrove and the two Miss Loftys, drove by in a coach and four; they didn't see me at first, but I saluted them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Oh, the devil's in your politeness! salute ladies from the Goat in Boots! Where did your noble honour dine?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Upon the mile-stone this side Sa∣lisbury. (Sir Hans stares) Sir, I had no occa∣sion to shut myself from the open air, as I had a couple of hard eggs in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Zounds! and I suppose you brought salt in your pocket?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, and a penny roll.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: His penny roll has choak'd me! and where did your honour take your bottle?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: True, Sir, I slipp'd off the bank into the river, as I was getting a little water in the brim of my hat.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: The devil take them that took you out again!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Father, the walking got me an ap∣petite; after my repast, I was neither dry nor hungry; I drank no wine; but then I was free from an head-ache, and, without mixing in com∣pany, my heart was chearful.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans. (aside)
SP.P:
This gay Arthur will make him another thing. Gadso! but Dickins will have the constables after him. George, you'll give me what information you've picked up in your tour; how they manage their machines
and lodging-houses; what they do, and what they don't do, that I may know what I ought to do.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Ca'n't make up that other six-pence —oh! the halfpenny to the boy for opening the gate!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Dem the boy; come polish your∣self up a little, my ward Miss Augusta Wood∣bine's come from London, and I've a certain reason for her thinking well of you. If she should see you so— (takes an handkerchief, and whisks the dust off)—such an appearance by the Lord seems as easy and satisfied, as if drest for a ball. Can nothing make you ashamed?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Thanky, Sir, I'll take care to do nothing that shall make me ashamed. You shall never see a blush in my face.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Plague of your blushing face, I mean your dingy appearance. Here's the Lady —I'll try what effect an accidental meeting may have. Now to know what they have done with the gay Arthur!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I sear I've lost my clothes brush.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Bless me! where can she be? if she has run home, and told papa, I shall have it in stile.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Fanny! how do you do, my love?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: My dear George! when did you come? Lord! I'm so glad!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: You look as charming as ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Thankye; but, upon my word, you don't look so charming.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I should make myself a little decent.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Then run home, and change your dress.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Oh, no occasion, I've my clothes brush in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Oh! governess, I've been running about after you.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: What could induce you to bring me into Lord Torrendel's house? sure you know that he is a very dangerous character.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Lord, its no such thing, who could have told you such a fib? his Lordship has no more pride! he's not asham'd at making one in a game of romps, even with his own servant maids.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Ah, Fanny, when our superiors of the other sex condescend to affability, instead of exalting, it is for the purpose of degrading us to a state of the most pitiable humiliation.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Now don't snub me, I'll introduce you to—

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Oh, no more of your introductions, pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: I will, tho'; Miss Augusta, this is—

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: A Mr. Steward, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! George you don't know what we're laughing at.— (apart) Miss, don't go tell him that I play at shuttlecock with my Lord in the great gallery.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P:
A piece of his Lordship's condescen∣sion
I didn't know before. My guardian's son, I presume.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: The description of Miss Augusta Woodbine falls short of what I have the happi∣ness to behold.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: There, I told you he was a smart fel∣low sometimes. Come, George, you shall be our chaperon about the town, but you are an odd-looking beau.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Well, I'll attend you on your ram∣bles — (aside) though I've already walked twelve miles to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Madam will you honour my arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Ha! here's odds. Madam, my arm is at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Do you know this Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Lord, true, this is Assembly night.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Gentlemen, treat the Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Hem! the Ladies don't want—shall we walk?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Quite a hound! ha! nectarines so early! Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Six are a guinea.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: There!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Oh! Sir, by no means.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Miss, an apple—Fanny!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P:
Sir, these are Angels, not Eves,
to be tempted by your paltry pippins.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir, what d'ye mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Woman.
SP.P: Good Gentlemen and Ladies, I've a sick husband lying in prison.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: For debt? what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Woman.
SP.P: Above eighteen shillings.

SP.SPEAKER: George. (loud)
SP.P: Pray go—don't teize people; their distress is only the consequence of idle∣ness. I'd never encourage beggars—there, go— (gives money apart) plagueing one.

SP.SPEAKER: Woman.
SP.P: Sir, it's a guinea!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Well, don't trouble one now. (loud) Get your husband out of prison, and comfort your child.
SP.STAGE: (apart; sings carelessly, and puts them off).

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: What's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Bless you, governess, George is al∣ways doing these kind of things. He'd grudge himself a penny cheesecake, yet maintains and clothes half the poor round; he's king of a small island near his father's seat.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: What a pitiful scoundrel am I. My guinea nectarines, and little penny-worth of pippins, with the benevolent heart of a god! Sir, if I dare beg the honour of your acquaint∣ance—I haven't a card, but I'm over at—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir, I'll put down your address; (takes out his pencil) points broke (takes out pen-knife) cutting it away—wastes— (puts up both) Oh, Sir, I'll remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: George, what signifies your bowing there? come and pay some attention to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur. (looking at Augusta).
SP.P: How charming! what a block am I, talking half an hour to a Lady, and never look'd at her!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Fanny, we must be walking towards your papa's.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: But you hav'n't seen our ball-room here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Ball-room. Ladies, do you know I'm a most capital dancing-master? harkye, my worthy friend, a word.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Oh! Sir, as many as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Lord! that rattle there has dragged George up into the Assembly-room; I hope its not to fight—ecod! if he goes to sight, George will kill him. (a fiddle heard above) That's he! I know his sweet little finger.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: What an astonishing resemblance! Fanny, did you ever see any likeness of this strange gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Ah! the image of Miss Woodbine's picture! its Lord Torrendel's great boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: The neglected son of my un∣happy cousin!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: To drive him in sorrow from his doors! my poor master now is sunk in grief and woe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur. (without)
SP.P: Bravo! (enters sing∣ing) Ladies, 'pon my word, my friend is an excellent stick; his respects to you, Miss, and my most humble adoration to you, Madam, we'll have a little dance above.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Oh, Sir! no, no! come Fanny.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Lud! it would be fine fun, governess don't you see how cloudy it gets; I'm sure there will be a shower, and if I walk thro' the rain, you, as my governess, ouglit to be very angry with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Fye, Ma'am, wou'd you spoil your dress? we shall have a dashing shower, a great drop fell on the tip of my nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: No, indeed! come Fanny.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: You, Sir, where's my mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: With your father. I left the picture in the porter's lodge; for the Frenchman has turn'd away the porter for letting you in.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Go back, and bring it to my lodgings, or I'll massacre you. (a fiddle heard without) Tol de rol lol! we'll be with you, boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: But, Sir, as George plays, where's my partner?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: I'll whistle, sing, and dance, all in a breath.
SP.STAGE: (puts an arm round each, and runs in)

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin. (whistles)
SP.P: A pity that Christians hav'n't a laughing and crying side to their faces; for, in a comfortabe fit of sorrow, up starts something to give us an he, he, he! and when the mouth's opened for a nice grin, up goes the finger in the eye with an ho, ho, ho!—but my face must take the humour and fortunes of my master; in the road of life the small must follow the great, and that's the reason the big coach-wheel runs after the little one.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—The Inn.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Landlady, introducing LADY TORRENDEL, and MISS CLARE.

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: Won't you please to rest, Ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: I thank you, but so long shut up in a carriage, one should rest walking. Miss Clare, will you be so kind as to ask the footman if I've left my memorandum-book in the coach? (exit Miss Clare) Some handsome equipages about here! have you many gentry in the town?

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: Oh, yes, Ma'am, we've a Lord, and Knight, and power of Squires.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Clare.
SP.P: Here, Ma'am, is the book.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Oh! I thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: I'll hasten the horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: My Lord had a seat in this part of the country, and I think a banking agent of his lives in this town. (looks in the book) Mr. Dickins, yes, very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Clare.
SP.P: This seems a charming place, my Lady!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P:
It is! I wish my Lord hadn't part∣ed with it! the castle and its delightful envi∣rons were the tranquil scenes of my most happy hours! after marriage our first years were pass'd here, and tho' there was title on his side, and great wealth on mine, yet ours was not a match of fashion! neither ambition on my part, or (I think) avarice on his; very young to be sure,
but then I was a little philosopher, tho' bred in the full brilliant certainty of every dazzling joy that riches cou'd bestow, yet my sight was proof against the glare of splendor. My Lord was gay, accomplish'd, and the generosity of a youthful mind repell'd all idea of advantage in our union.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Clare.
SP.P: Ah, Madam! any Gentleman must think himself possess'd of every advantage in a union with your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: I wish I had myself gone to Lisbon with my Lord; this journey seems so tedious, and then the uncertainty of the seas; thro' his indisposition he may want that tender cordiality, his claim from me; I'm all anxiety to proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Madam, the horses are too, but does your Ladyship know my Lord's here?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Here! how! what do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: In this very town my Lady, I met our old Martha.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Impossible! return'd to England! something very mysterious—

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins. (without)
SP.P: Well, what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet. (without)
SP.P: I cannot talk my Lor's business in public entré.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Eh, why—sure that is my Lord's valet.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Clare.
SP.P: It certainly is, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Hush, step this way, Heavens! oh, my heart will—Martha you say—tell me—

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Really, since my Lord's losty con∣duct to me, I shall give up his affairs. I've my agencies, and my bank to mind.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Bank! vat! de little till in your boutique? you had better send challenge to mi Lor—swell and puff! ma soi! c'est comique ca! let mi Lor take his money out of your bank, den vat is your bladder of consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: 'Slbood I don't want any body to take their money out of my bank.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Here be a fresh pacquet of letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Which I am to forward, as usual, to Lady Torrendel in Cumberland.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: I have date 'em, so as to make mi Lady believe my Lor still at Lishon.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: To keep the unsuspecting wife cool amongst the lakes there, while the gallant husband enjoys his rose-buds in his pleasure grounds here.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Mi Lor, to spare himself, still finesse de sprain hand, and trouble me vid de vife—so dere I ave writ dat whole bundle for her at vonce. I ave upon my mind des affaires d'importance to get de pretty girl for mi Lor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: And I, as a magistrate, have to send this young dog to prison, who has been taking up the tradesmen's goods.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Magistrate! fi done! petit bour∣geois —you huff abaut pah!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Who cares for your paw, or your four claws, you damned outlandish cockatoo! I must send these one by one, which first?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: My Lord in England all this time!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Dated this day—"to Lady Tor∣rendel."

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: How's this!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Then to give time for her to sup∣pose it came from her Lord at Lisbon, where he has not been at all, her Ladyship shall have this in about a month.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: A little sooner, if you please, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Lady Torrendel hereself!
SP.STAGE: (drops the letters, and exit consused. Enter Miss Clare; picks them up, and presents)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor. (opening one)
SP.P: Separate himself from me by such a complicated series of invention, and by fallacious accounts of his ill-health, keep me in perpetual uneasiness! cruel man! make me believe he had sold his estate here, yet re∣tain it only for the base purpose of converting a spot (that brings to my mind the sweet re∣collection of delight, and innocence) into a contaminated retreat for licentious, guilty, sor∣did pleasures! you charg'd the coachman not to mention who I am? but I fear that now is too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Clare.
SP.P: No, Ma'am, for his own discre∣tion suggested the necessity of that, before I mentioned it to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Do you think too, if the people of this house know it, I can engage them to keep my arrival a secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Clare.
SP.P:
The woman promises that, for tho' my Lord spends so much money, he's no
favourite in the town, from the knowledge of his ill usuage of your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: I wou'dn't have him dispised; but how to gain full and certain proofs? to put be∣yond all doubt his motive for secreting himself here?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Clare.
SP.P: So far I have taken the liberty of anticipating your Ladyship's wish. I have ask'd Martha—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: My good friend! a thousand thanks! I'm charm'd with your zeal. Yes, it is my wish; what! Martha will convey me privately into the Castle? delightful! I think none of his servants know me here, but his French Secretary. Write to me by a servant! not open my Letters! unkind! ungrateful! but then, to steal upon him, its a severe trial—I'm faint! but I must summon fortitude! they'll see I've been weeping; come—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. Dickins's parleur: large books lying on the table.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Step in, only stop a moment, my mas∣ter will be in directly, and take all your infor∣mations. You know I can do nothing in it.

SP.SPEAKER: First Man.
SP.P: The young Gentleman is thought∣less and wild, but I believe there's not much harm in him.

SP.SPEAKER: Second Man.
SP.P: I don't think I can find in my heart to prosecute, if the affair is likely to af∣fect his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Third Man.
SP.P: He's but a bad one I sear, yet I'd not hang a man for all the boots I'm worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: So, the Lady has got into the Castle. Ecod! she'll trim his gay Lordship—yes, she has stole a march upon him—he sha'n't hear of it from one. Oh what curtain lectures, per∣haps a divorce, then maybe he'll marry my Fanny. No, he's a damn'd impudent fellow; a pretty business, this young buck—

SP.SPEAKER: Third Man.
SP.P: If he can raise the money to pay me I don't wish to hurt him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Pay you, oh! the Devil, I shall lose my sees! (aside) You selfish dog, would you compound a felony: Some revenge upon the father, to have the great family-name of D'Au∣merle down in a Mittimus.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Fellow, where's your pris'ner?

SP.SPEAKER: Constable.
SP.P: Please your worship, he be daunc∣ing— he desired me to gi' you this bit of pa∣per.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: What the devil! I send you for a thief, and you bring me a bit of paper—"he be dauncing." (reads) "Lord Arthur D'Aumerle's compliments to Justice Dickins, is now engaged with some Ladies, but after another dance will wait upon"—dance!

SP.SPEAKER: Constable.
SP.P: Yez, there bes young Squire Bur∣gess got fiddling, and Miss Fanny, ecod they be gigging it up rarely.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P:
My daughter! is this the first lesson
from her new Governess! but you stupid scoun∣drel, I suppose you took a bribe.

SP.SPEAKER: Constable.
SP.P: Noa, Sir, I only took half-a-crown.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: How dare you, only a Constable, meddle with the Justice's business. A notorious offender; charged with crimes of life and death! he come! no! he'll abscond—we sha'n't see him in a hurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: I want the Justice!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Why, that's he, but damn me if you find Justice here (aside) I must examine the cul∣prit in form; you, sirrah! John, what the devil are you about in the shop, when I want you in my office? weighing raisins and pepper; down with the scales and balance, and bring my great books, and my ink-stand, and my wig, aye! and I'll take my chocolate here.
SP.STAGE: Muffins, &c. brought in; Dickins places books, puts on wig, and sits.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: I've finished our Coranto in a quick step, and, with a kiss hand to the Ladies, have flown to receive your commands.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins. (aside)
SP.P: Now, is this folly, impu∣dence, courage, or generosity?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Upon the information of the butter'd muffins, Justice Dickins, I presume—
SP.STAGE: (sits on the table, and begins eating)

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: What the devil! Sir, upon the infor∣mation of the Constable, a great rogue I pre∣sume— but pon honor I didn't expect you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Oh! then, Sir, your most obe∣dient!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Stop! stop! is this the man that took your goods?

SP.SPEAKER: Tradesinan.
SP.P: Yes!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Enough! write his mittimus—you all prosecute; what's your name Mr.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Lord Arthur D'Aumerle.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Alias Duke of Dunstable, alias Cap∣tain, alias Major.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Was my father still in the army, I'd have enlisted a common soldier in his own regiment—then the world might have said, there's Lord Torrendel's son carrying a knap∣sack— but now let it say, a parent suffers his child to lie in prison for the necessaries of life. Cou'dn't you carry me to gaol by the castle?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Constable, you have my authority, take him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: No man in England shall take him. So then, you've met with George—made him dance—bravo! but, my prince of bold actions, what are they going to do with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Conduct him to prison!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: I'll bail him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Pray be quiet, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: I wo'n't be quiet, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: But, here's an assault and battery— must be bound over to keep the peace for a year and a quarter—no, a year and a day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: I'll answer for him! aye, two thou∣sand pounds! there's my name; fill up the instrument.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P:
Oh! very well: he'll save his neck,
and you'll lose your money—let him out now, and catch him again if you can.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Does your little rascally soul conceive I'd let a friend suffer for an act of be∣nevolence, and to myself? No! human laws may punish other crimes; but, let the hottest bolt of heaven strike ingratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin. (without)
SP.P: Sweet Mr. Constable, 'pon my salvation I didn't—

SP.SPEAKER: Constable.
SP.P: Measter, here bes an accomplish.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: I'm not accomplish'd, I'm quite a bog trotter.

SP.SPEAKER: Constable.
SP.P: The picture that was robb'd out of—

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: What, you found it upon him?

SP.SPEAKER: Constable.
SP.P: Upon his very head.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: You notorious criminal!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: My master to be jumping about with Ladies, and leave me—oh! my dear Sir! (runs to Lord Arthur. Tradesman whispers. Timolin pointing to Sir Hans) did he! then plaise your honour, will you be bound bail for me too?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: For you! pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: No, Sir! ask them to pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: I'll bail my servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: You! a rare shadow! ah! friend, I know you. Thanks to the noble Lord Torren∣del's gallantries, we've twenty such Lords cut∣ting cabbages, and drudging for oysters down at Sandgate Island—but because your mother had a pretty face, a great fortune, and no vir∣tue—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Throw a reflection on the me∣mory of my honour'd parent! defame the sacred memory of the dead—the only universal epitaph—oblivion to the frailties of huma∣nity!— I'll murder him, by heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: No occasion to swear, you've said it, and you'll do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Han.
SP.P: Hold! the devil's in you; break the peace, and I lose my two thousand pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: True, my dear friend—oh! I burn with fury—but your Worship's wig ca'n't swear a battery. (twirls it) There's Burn's Justice, Blackstone, and Coke upon Littleton. (knocks tables about) Come along, Timolin.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Master, stay for me—take me—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Oh! what a bright model for my son George!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—An antique Room in the Castle.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Constable, and L'OEILLET, pushing in TI∣MOLIN.

SP.SPEAKER: Loeillet.
SP.P: There, you stay fast, coquin! such audace—of robbery, take surniture and pictures out of my Lor's house!

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I'm more guilty than my master, as the receiver is worse than the thief.

SP.SPEAKER: Constable.
SP.P: Who is your master, the receiver? speak!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Friend, you may take me for a rob∣ber, if you will; but you shan't prove me an in∣former, because I've a regard for my cha∣racter.

SP.SPEAKER: Loeillet.
SP.P: Stay there till we find Mr. Dickin, de justice, to send you to jail; be merry with that table and chair; sorry to disgrace—make a brown bear of my chamber—there sit and sing —"de charge is prepared, de lawyers are met."

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P:
