I wish they had crammed me into a jail at once, and not took me up in this dis∣mal top of a castle. Oh did my poor mother ever think that, before I died, I should get my∣self hanged for a thief? Lord Arthur! Lord Ar∣thur! unlucky was the day that Mr. Felix Ti∣molin hired to be your servant man. (looking at the table) Here's letters and papers, scribble scrabble, eh! why, this is my Lord's own hand, I remember it by one of his Franks— To
Monsieur Loeillet, what does he write to his servants; but what's all this to me; no way to get out of window, may be in this closet.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter, at a secret door, LADY TORRENDEL, and MARTHA.

SP.SPEAKER: Martha. (surprised)
SP.P: Why, I vow my Lady, this is the valet's room, and none of us ever knew this door to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: I think, Martha, I remember the castle better than you, who have lived in it so long. Out of that door there's a stair-case to my Lord's dressing-room, where I'll wait till he comes in. I'd wish to know a little more be∣fore I see him. Rather mean this lurking about and tampering with servants—but no hope of reclaiming him, except he's certain I know what then will be out of his power to deny. (aside) My Lord rode out you say; formed discomposed? well, not a word that I'm here, (Martha returns) this house seems all wild, no regularity, peace, or the comforts of a home, but the gratification of passions which reason and nature now should subdue, reconciles him to inquietude, meanness, and dishonour. So, this room now belongs to his vile agent! it was formerly put to a better purpose—this is the very room I converted to a school for the poor infant rustics. Here the young mind was trained to virtue and industry—here now, are perhaps, plans laid to corrupt and destroy the sweet rose of innocence! Eh, who's here!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: No, looks into a deep court. Oh, I'm very high up, they've double locked the door. (trying it) Oh dear! oh dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Dos'nt seem to be one of the fa∣mily!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: This letter, from my Lord to Mon∣sieur, I've a strong curiosity to see.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: How! as I'm here on a voyage of discovery, the sight of that might prepare me better for this dreaded interview with my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: It's ungenerous to look into another man's letter, only I'd like to see the rastiest mode of writing. I'm told its not the fashion now to cross the t's, and put little tittles on the i's; no harm to see that sure— (reads)The sight of this boy has troubled me exceedingly!— Boy! oh, that's my master; (reading)Pro∣bably, I shan't be home before evening, but if you can contrive to get Augusta into your power, the better. She may be brought down to Sandgate island—Oh, here's villainy!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor. (aside)
SP.P: Some poor intended victim! My coming at such a time is highly fortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin (reads).
SP.P:
Pray have an eye upon that Arthur's ill-looking Irishman—Oh, that crowns his rogueries— No harm to keep Augusta under lock and key. I'll keep this proof of their wickedness, and if they talk of hanging me for a bit of an old picture, I'll bring it out in the nose of their shabby red faces— ill looking Irishman—eh, one would think they took me for Miss Augusta. (sees Lady Tor.)
Then they have locked you up? you most un∣happy beautiful soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Why he takes me for the present object of pursuit! by giving into this mistake, I may discover some more of my husband's at∣chievements. (aside) Are you his Lordship's emissary?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: I, Miss! I despise such doings.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: I believe it; your sace speaks ho∣nesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Then it speaks truth, and the devil himself shan't make it tell a lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: But, who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: My master is his Lordship's son that's at this instant shifting about, and can't get a beef-steak without venturing his neck for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: True—Martha told me of this un∣happy destitute youth—Oh, husband! false to me, and unnaturally cruel to the offspring of your follies.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Miss, I'll assure you, Lord Arthur is as brave a little boy—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: And bears his forlorn state with meekness and resignation?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Oh yes! Miss, he's as meek and gentle—ah, hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor. (aside).
SP.P: Poor youth, he has a fa∣ther, and yet an orphan! Then he shall find a friend in me—though not mine, he belongs to the man I still love! but to continue this de∣ception—cou'd you contrive any means for me to fly this mansion of shame and ruin?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P:
Offer to come in to touch her, and,
by the mighty powers of heaven, I'll slay you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Oh!
SP.STAGE: (runs in. The door's burst open, and enter Lord Arthur.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Suffer me to perish, and im∣prison my faithful squire for his attachment! Put your arms a-kimbo, sirrah, stump down those great stairs with your hat on, and let me see who dares squint at you—Oh! that lovely divine Augusta!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: What! then you've seen her, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: What do you stand winking and making faces there, sirrah? come out.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: But there's somebody else lock'd up.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Kick up your legs boldly, no matter whose shins are in the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: But, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: B'y'r leave there for Mr. Fe∣lix Timolin.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. A Street.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Aye! and well George?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: We had a dance, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: As if he had said we had a funeral. 'Sblood! man, say—we had a dance. (capers) Arthur was master of the ceremonies—you shuffled it away? eh, boy?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I was'nt afraid to shuffle, for I had my thick walking shoes on.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Shoes! asses' hoofs! I believe they're half an inch thick.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, they're an inch. (aside) I must see if the poor woman has released her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: George, so 'twas you rasp'd up the fiddle for them?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, so we had no fiddler to pay.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Psha! I'd hire Handel's anniver∣sary band to see you dance the Cameronian Rant with Augusta. This scheme of leaving her at large wo'nt do—she'll be snapt up. Gad, yon∣der she is—I must clench this business. Why do you put on that dismal look, sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I was thinking, father, of the cruelty in keeping people in prison for small debts above a twelvemonth however; liberty's so sweet, they'd purchase it if in their power, if not, hard to punish a man for only being unfor∣tunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Here comes Miss Augusta. Devil's in your thick soal'd shoes!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusla.
SP.P: That man certainly whispered something disagreeable that caused the abrupt departure of Lord Arthur.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Dear no, he's a very civil soul, why 'twas papa's constable. Oh my good gracious, if here is'nt George.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P:
Your waistcoat's buttoned all crooked —no powder in your hair—by the lord! you look like the dustman. (apart) Well Miss, how do
you like your new situation?—stop, I want to speak to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Stop, he wants to speak to us—how do you do, George?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Ha! very free with George! (aside) Miss Woodbine, I've your good at heart. Your uncle's whim, in taking his fortune from you, makes you an object of compassion.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Many would rather be an object of envy—but, to my thinking, an humble state is preferable to affluence, built upon the ruins of unmerited adversity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans. (aside)
SP.P: Made for each other! (a∣part) George, to her in her own way—out with your handkerchief, and cry for the poor debtors. My son, Miss, is so happy to see—to be with you—

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Happy to see her? but I'm sure its no such thing, old codger.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: He expressed great joy at your coming so opportunely.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Opportunely indeed! (looking at his stockings) Miss, could you lend me a needle and thread?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Go along you rascal, sortune! I'll bind you apprentice to a taylor.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: You're happy, Sir, in having a son of so much frugality for his years.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Frugal, ma'am! he's the most ex∣travagant—

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: I see now he only wants them to like each other; I must prevent this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P:
Why, look now, with his coat over his knuckles; he has on lace ruffles at three guineas a pair. Pull down your ruffles. (pulls George's wristbands down) By the lord! he has got into
hopsack. What have you done with all the fine linen and lace I sent you?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: The lace was too fine for use—but the Holland made soft child-bed linen for the curate's wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Yes, madam, the bishop's lady was the good woman in the straw. He is very frolicksome—it's a shame for you to be such a buck.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Lord, Miss, George is no buck! he's a mere milk sop, an't you George?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Get away you little devil, who wants your prate. (apart) Miss, we'll conceal your loss from my son—he's so proud—see how he throws his head about. (apart) George, with Augusta's cash, you can do such pretty charities! Son, this lady is worth one hundred thousand pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Lord, how can you tell such fibs— George, she's only my governess, and as poor —borrowed five shillings from me just now to release her box from the waggon—say you did.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Get along you little busy thing (apart). You know, ma'am, you're an im∣mense fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sir, I am neither ambitious of com∣passion or ridicule.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: George, never mind—she's very rich.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Oh no, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Zounds! Madam, you're a Jew.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: My governess is not a Jew, she has more religion than the bishop.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P:
The devil's in me, if I don't make your father pull your ears! (apart) Miss, my
son has a most liberal mind, a soul of magnisi∣cent extravagance.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Madam, my father is only jesting.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: True, George, now that's very good, Sir Hans is always making his sun of every body.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: By the Lord, overthrowing my whole scheme. (aside) Hop home you little magpie.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Madam, be assured, I esteem oecono∣my the first virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Then the devil's in you both! but it's you, prating monkey, has done it all; you, you rascal, with your oeconomy and asses' hooss, truff down to Samphire Hall; and you, Miss, stalk with your poverty to Mr. Dickins, the banker's.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Madam, your humble servant!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Devil's in your humble servant, you civil scoundrel! some mad gander will tuck her and her fortune under his wing, and hop off to Gretna Green.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: George sent down to the rocks, oh! oh! then I know where somebody will go. (aside) Sir Hans, your most obedient, good morning to you, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Oh very polite Ma'am, but I wish you had dropt your curtsy half an hour ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta. (looking out)
SP.P: The forlorn thought∣less Arthur! Sir, tell me—is Miss Woodbine's son my uncle's heir? then why not instantly ex∣tricate him, from the embarrassing perplexities that must end in his destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P:
What son? (looking out) The gay Arthur! true, Lord Torrendel's; (aside) oh ho!
I suspect there's love here—this was her dancing partner. My dear, as to affection and all that, this Arthur—

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sir, I am only interested for him, on account of my cousin Woodbine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Right! for his heart is engaged to a girl, he told me all over a glass of hock. (Augusta agitated)(aside) Yes! she likes him— then, in one word, Miss Augusta, my dear, I'll not part with you, till I see you and my son fairly coupled.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur. (without)
SP.P: Sir Hans!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Yes, Sir! past three.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Past three! Don't much like his avoiding me, and taking the lady. His bail∣bond may keep me from limbo—but mustn't rob me of paradise either.

DIV3.P: Run, sirrah, after Miss Augusta, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Back again to your father's?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: You will persist, we left Miss Augusta there; (takes a bit of paper, and writes with pencil) if I can but obtain the love of this charming girl, she's so beautiful, elegant—but then, very modest; I'll have her—oh! Timolin, I will have her, run with this letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: With what?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Stop to ask questions with your hows and whats—run, take this letter to the young lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P:
Oh! I'll give no letters to ladies. Do you want, Sir, to carry on your father's pro∣fligate rigmarolds? but you don't make a French
Mounseer of me—for the spirit of Mr. Felix Timolin is a peg above that, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: What! walk back, if you please, into Castle Quad.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Then 'pon my word, I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: How, you scoundrel! do you object to go into prison when I—? begone! I discharge you.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Oh! Sir, I discharge myself, and there's a receipt for my wages. (snaps his fingers) I'd hazard my life, to procure you what you might again repay—but, helping you to take the innocence you could never return, is beneath the soul of Mr. Felix Timolin.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Dem it! now I've lost him. I had no conception of this mighty Irish honour of his brave soul. He has had moral, from his rustic parent in his mud cabin; but, I never knew a father's kind precept or good example.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter COACHMAN, surveys LORD ARTHUR at a distance.
DIV3.P: What does this fellow eye me for?

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: My Lady sent me to know his person—yes! that's he, very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: You're no Coachman, my friend you're a bailiff—they take all disguises.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. A walk near Lord Torrendel's

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P:
To divert mi Lor from de thought of dis tapageur, son of his, I must get off Miss
Augusta for him; but, to see more of this letter of instruction—eh! oh! I have left it on the table in my room—Thomas have borrow Sir Hans's livery to carry her sham message; but if there be danger, we yet want some strong, able, desperate—

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: I could be contented with one dinner in three days, because it's a thing I've practis'd with some success—but, my poor dear mas∣ter—

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Oh! you be got out, where I did lock you—

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Here, lock me up again; for I've lost my master, and I don't care how I am.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: I suppose you be not overcharg'd vid money, and I take it you be fripon—in your character, roguery be the leading feature.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: I judge that your nose is your lead∣ing feature—so I take it. (advancing) I, a rogue! produce a proof that I'm one.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Here be a stirling proof.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: So, because you've money, you've a right to call a poor man out of his name.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet. (gives it)
SP.P: Dere now, call me out of my name.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin. (looking at it)
SP.P: Then, you're an ho∣nest man a genteel noble lad. If I can find my lord, this will carry us back to town.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P:
Arreté! dat is for service you vill do me. (looking out) Milor! go! dat footman vill tell you vat it be. Besides, more reward,
if you should be taken up again for little pecca∣dilloz, milor's interest vill release you. Allez!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Paid for doing good before hand! now I've gold and a clear conscience, two com∣panions that are seldom together now a day's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: That fellow of Arthur's still lurk∣ing about here!

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Peste! quelle ballourdise! I have made fine confident in my Lord's scheme, (aside) O! my Lord, he only ask—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: I hope you have'n't let this affair go further than those already concerned?

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Oh! no, my Lord! if he knew I had employed this Irishman, I am undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: L'Oeillet, I've improved upon your plan. Thomas's being in Sir Hans's livery may not be sufficient to persuade Augusta, that she is really sent for by him—now if you could borrow Sir Hans's post chaise, that would ef∣fectually remove suspicion—make any excuse, he'll be glad to oblige me.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Diantre! here I go for Sir Hans's coach to carry off Miss Augusta, and have set Thomas and the Irishman to take her off with horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Why, L'Oeillet, you don't seem over hearty in the cause now?

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Oh! I'm devoted to your Lord∣ship's service.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Once wheedled into the carriage, a pretext is soon found to get her to Sandgate Island.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Ah! mais cest que cest excellent ca!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: About it now—I shall be there before you.

SP.SPEAKER: L'Oeillet.
SP.P: Pardi! dis is lucky—for now I vill do it myself. I vish tho' I cou'd meet vid dis maroufle, to hinder him meddle in de affair— dat malheureux Irish tief vill do me some mis∣chief.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—A Road.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter TIMOLIN, and THOMAS, in Sir Hans's Livery.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Thomas, I know all your plan, now you've told me. So here you've borrowed Sir Hans's livery from one of his ser∣vants, and you're to go and tell Miss Augusta, he has sent you for her—but, as you may be a cowardly kind of chap, the Mounseer has bid me assist you with my tight bit of arm. Hush! here she comes

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: I thought she was a little girl just left school.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: I don't know, whether she she goes to school or no—but, this is the very Miss Au∣gusta, that was lock'd up in the castle with me. (aside) Oh! I'll make a neat example of ye all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P:
My mind is in a state of the most tormenting solicitude! I wish I knew where to find
this young lady, and apprize her of my Lord's designs. Whether to return and wait for him? I dread the interview, unkind upbraiding often shakes the very basis of affection. Yet I know he'll endeavour, by some artful evasion, to slip from my charge, except I can bring it to a full conviction—but first to afford this poor young man assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Young man, that must be me—she saw I was in distress.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Deliver this to him, without let∣ing him know who it comes from.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Stop! I'm here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Oh, his servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Now, this goodness to me, has de∣termined me, in what I was resolved upon; to save her from all danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Perhaps I may now learn, who this young lady is.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin. (To Thomas)
SP.P: Go you, and stay with your horses—I'll deliver the message to her my∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: But you're not in Sir Hans's livery —It wo'n't take her.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: How d'ye do, Miss Augusta?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor. (aside)
SP.P: My trusty champion's mis∣taking me for her, I find, continues.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Miss, your guardian, Sir Hans Bur∣gess, hopes for your company down at Sam∣phire-Hall—he has sent horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: I'll whisper a few words, that shall bring her directly. Harkye, Miss! don't go, this is a rogue, that wants to coax you again into the mouse-trap.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: You mistake—I'm not the person.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: That's a good thought to deny your∣self —I'll second it—are you sure you never saw Miss Augusta before now?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Then this is not she—so go about your business.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: He wants to inveigle you, to Lord Torrendel.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Indeed! this is charming, as I supposed! the most lucky opportunity to do good, prevent evil, save the innocent from ruin, and overwhelm the guilty in the blushing shame of his own base intentions. (aside) I was ap∣prehensive of some error—you've brought horses you say—very well, I'll—wait on my guardian.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Then you are Miss Augusta. Why, what did you mean just now by—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Yes, yes, you're right enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: If they take you for a Lady, that will fly off to an old libertine, they're right enough indeed; but I was wrong, when I thought you a bit of an angel.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Come.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: A word, ma'am! your charitable intentions just now about me, were good—but, since you give yourself up to this old reprobate, I scorn your assistance, and, if a little turn of virtue, should ever make you repent of your non∣sense, don't expect any defence from the soul of Mr. Felix Timolin.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P:
Heavens! I leave a shocking impres∣sion on the mind of this worthy creature. (aside)
Well, well, we shall find time to clear my cha∣racter.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: An old rotten potatoe for your cha∣racter! bye and bye, when you're seen flourish∣ing in curricles, with a different gallant every day, stuck up at your elbow, you'll still be chat∣tering about your character, to all the turn∣pike-men.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Yes! it is a baliss—he's at my heels. Timolin, do you see any door open? stand in that spot, you scoundrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Oh! if any more of those compli∣ments pass between you and me, it's a toss up who's to pay them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: If he don't touch me, it's no caption.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: He's returning with the money, the gay miss gave him for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: I've had a good chace after you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Attempt to give me the tip, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman. (taking papers from his pocket)
SP.P: Here it is—this bill for three hundred pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: If it was ten thousand, I wou'dn't ac∣cept it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: You villain, do I want you to accept bills for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: It's a good note, and your own too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P:
Well, I know I have notes and
bonds enough out—but if I pay one of them, I'll be damn'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Sir, don't frighten yourself, about what doesn't concern you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, sirrah; of my own accord, I came from our dance, when old Wighum, the justice, sent for me; but, compell'd, I will not go; so let the plaintiff carry the bills in to my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Now, Sir, you're too nice. I promised to do the business, and I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Aye! he only wants to touch me.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Arrah! what signifies your dancing round me, like a couple of May-poles?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Oh, how my fingers—Ti∣molin, knock him down—I wonder whether it's a capture if I touch him.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: What are you at with your caps, and hats? The English of he thing is—Miss Au∣gusta, I despise.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Speak o of my divine charmer.

DIV3.STAGE: Strikes him, and runs off, Coachman after.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Oh! if he discharges me, and comes once a day to give me a knock in my cheek, I'm to have a blessed life of it—tho' my honour wou'd not suffer me to take relief from this Miss Augusta, yet I'll try and get the reward from Mounseer. For, if I was to preach in a pulpit as high as Patrick's steeple, the ladies, and gentlemen, would be running after one another, and, till they give roast beef for nothing, to mere honesty, a guinea is convenient in an empty pocket.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—Samphire hall: Sir Hans's, and other Houses:—A view of the Sea, bathing Machines, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: A month since i've been down here at my favourite rocks. How do the lodging-houses go on? I hope they keep low with their prices, till the place is known. Aye! I may yet see Samphire-Hall, eclipse Brighton, Weymouth, and Scarborough.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Yez! your honour; for the young Squire has set up a staple commodity of trade, and already the volks bes so merry about'n. You know Humphry Grin, the stone mason, is famous in the letter cutting way—Measter George had gin the freedom of the quarry, and he has established a manufacture for tomb∣stones.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Tomb-stones to make people merry!

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P:
He has finished half a dozen choice epitaphs with:
Afflictions zore
Long time I bore,
Physicians were in wain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Devil's in his physicians!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: That was certainly Lord Torrendel turn'd into the green lane—muffled up, and seem'd hiding his face. Robin gave me a hint of his designs upon Fanny.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: A sweet morning concert for the rooms, of chipping and sawing! Tell Master Grin, he must depart in peace with his merry monuments, from this part of the world. Did you hire a new postillion?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Yez, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans. (Seeing George.)
SP.P: Don't come near me—get a tin pot and a bit of stick, and pick up cockles on the beach—you haven't a soul above a cockle-gatherer, you cursed otter. Robin! have they put up the shelves in the raffling shop?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir, the men are working at their looms.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Looms!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Instead of encouraging frauds, cheat∣ing strangers with paltry toys, I have erected looms, that will give bread to two industrious families.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Hans.
SP.P: Why, they're Weavers!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, sir, weavers of stockings, gloves, and mittins.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: A stocking loom in the place of my elegant raffling shop!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: There's a ribband loom too. This was the first wove in it; for the motto's sake, put it in your hat.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans. (reads)
SP.P:
"Success to Commerce, and lasting happiness to England." Well, let Industry throw the shuttle to this motto with all
my heart. What smoke's that yonder? clink∣ing of hammers! by the lord it's—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, it's the forge I built for poor old Grimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: What, a smith?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, a worthy blacksmith.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Within the very walls of my cold bath, old Grimes blowing his bellows!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: What use for a cold bath just on the verge of the ocean? and the farmers want the necessary tools for blessed agriculture.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: I banish you for ever, from my fashionable bathing place. You barbarous young savage! after my high puff advertisements of cold larders, neat wines, circulating libraries, baths, concerts, balls, billiards, machines, and bathing-caps, to expect to drag people of fashion down here, amongst stocking-looms, tombstones, and bellows-clinkers!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Father, my little colony was famish∣ing on Lord Torrendel's island. Since I have brought them here, in pity don't disturb them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: A fine ragged colony you've planted.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Consider, Father, industry is a flower that should be encouraged by the genial warmth of patronage.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: By the lord! the fellow's only fit for a plowman, or a weaver.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Well, Sir, the one gives bread, the other cloathing; as a plowman and a weaver are the most useful characters, I know of none more noble.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P:
Ah plague on it don't talk to me, my very servants will despise you you dog, I
dare say not one of 'em would stir a stump to save your soul and body, you young Beaver.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Your purse, Sir—I found it on the road.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Thank you, Robin,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: George's purse! how much was in it?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: More than I can tell—once I knew it to be master George's, I never put finger on the cash it held.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Suppose it had been my purse?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Ecod! your honor, you might never have seen it again: Gold's a tempting thing, and I don't set up for more honesty than my neighbours; but young Squire's money already belongs to the poor, and he bez a bad man in∣deed that wou'd take, what the generous heart is so ready to give.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Eh, now Robin, you've been playing tricks, knocking my purse about—its all broke —stupid fellow, I dare say you'd take better care of your own!

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: La, Sir, I have no purse, only a little bit of a leather bag, to divide a few shillings from the halfpence.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Whole, and sound, shou'dn't have thought of your impudence—tearing one's pro∣perty—there's my broken one, I shall keep yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: But, Sir, the gold's in it.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P:
Never mind, keep it Robin, you're
an honest fellow; honesty is a true diamond, and should be set in gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: My generous boy, George, build up and pull down, just as you please; (in rap∣ture) the rich man's safest guard, is the blessings of charity; but gold is the grand staple of your trade of benevolence—I've brought Miss Wood∣bine, and her fortune; go and entertain her.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Isn't that Lord Torrendel's French∣man.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Your honor, Mounseer's come from his Lord, to borrow your post-chay—going on a visit, and his own be broke.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Here's an oportunity to oblige my Lord. He shall have it, and hansel my new postillion too.

SP.SPEAKER: George. (aside)
SP.P: Some knavery in this post∣chaise! Robin, a word.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Here still; hop to the Lady, you curst curlew! hold, here she is.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.P: 'Twas certainly Arthur cross'd the road. (aside.) Sir, I've walk'd out, to see your charming place here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Hem!—I bid him speak to the Lady, and by the lord he's whispering Robin; George, address her with rapture.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, Sir! Madam, the—great—plea∣sure of—Robin.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: The great pleasure of—Robin! oh! the devil's in you, for a fine amorous scoundrel! Stop, you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.P: This young gentleman is an unadorned casket, enclosing the most delicate springs of sensibility; but that heart is not for me; or rather mine is not for him. I must not cherish an hopeless passion for Arthur; if, as Sir Hans tells me, another possesses his affections.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: My dear governess, I've got down to you; I'm only come, because you are here— where's George?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: You only come because I'm here— "where's George!" Ah, Fanny!

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: I've made papa bring me too—by a monstrous fib though. I've told him, Sir Hans wants him on most prodigious business.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Distanced the nabber! my lovely partner! who could expect to find you here, like a sea-nymph sent from old Neptune's palace, to make mortals plunge into the ocean, enamoured from this divine specimen of aquatic beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Most heroically gallant indeed, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Now for something gallant to me— How d'ye do, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Ah! little titmouse, suppose, my love, you step and gather a few honeysuckles from the hedge yonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: George might have had the manners to meet, and make nymphs of other people. Titmouse, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Madam, you see before you, a fellow the most wretched— (aside) shall I venture to declare my love? no—farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Whither, Sir, are you going?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: The truth is, Madam, tho' Great-Britain's large, I'm drove to the water's edge, where I'll step into, and push off the first fishing boat I can find; for abandon'd by my father, and pursued by—England, Ma∣dam, is no home for me. If I can get across the channel, amongst camps, and batteries, my empty sconce may keep a bullet from a head that has brains in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Your fortunes, Sir, are not, per∣haps, so desperate—your mother was—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: How! Madam, have you heard?— she is I hope an angel—and you my heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Overtaken you at last!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: I'll be damn'd if you have though.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: I'll be damn'd but I will though!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Unhappy youth! they'll pursue him to despair; but I'm usurping a concern that be∣longs to the mistress of his heart; yet, tho' I must not love, am I to reject all feelings of humanity.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny. (joyful)
SP.P: Oh! governess, I have asked the postillion to give us a roll on the beach—you don't know half this sweet place.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: In the chaise I may have a better chance of seeing which way he takes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny. (aside)
SP.P: Mustn't tell 'twas my Lord's valet proposed our ride, she's so squeamish.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Does Sir Hans know of this jaunt?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Very true—he may not let us go; I have if, sit in the chaise till I come; I'll fetch your hat and cloak.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Is this prudent, but no time for re∣flection, Arthur may be lost for ever.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—A parlour in Sir HANS'S.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Devilish good place the Knight has got here; a fine prospect of the sea; a pretty mortgage; and I may pick up such a bit as this, with Torrendel's interest—what can this be, Sir Hans has sent for me!

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: My Governess is so giddy—where can she have lest her hat.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Oh, Fanny, where's your friend Au∣gusta? you seem all upon the fidgets.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny. (confused)
SP.P: Oh no, Sir.—Lud! the two old boys will be running after us—what can I think of to keep them here? oh, true, my fine fib. (aside) Papa, I wonder why Sir Hans has sent for you; do you know?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: No, child, but I shall if I can get to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Here he is, ha, ha, ha! (aside) only look papa, what a fine prospect at that win∣dow; you can see, I believe, to the Isle of Wight.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Oh no; but very fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Fanny, where's your papa?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: He's there, Sir, but his head is so full of this serious affair, he's come down to tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Oh, very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: He, he, he; now each will be so full of expectation of the other telling, when there is nothing to tell, it may bring them into a squabble, and that will keep them as close as a game of backgammon—but deuce, where's Augusta's hat? he, he, he.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Ah, Dickins! how do you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins. (turning)
SP.P: Oh, Sir Hans, well, I've trundled down to you in a whiff.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Then the affair is very urgent? sit down.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Of consequence, I hope; for I had 2 good deal to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Haus.
SP.P: And so?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Well

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Well? so sudden, I was alarmed? but does it concern me so much?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: That you best know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: How the Devil should I know!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins. (peevish)
SP.P: Well then, when you tell me, perhaps I may know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: When you tell me, perhaps I may not know. But come.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Ave?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: The fellow's afraid of being over∣heard I suppose; come, I'll fasten the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Oh, if it is of so much consequence, and secrecy, I'll fasten this door too. (both rise and go to opposite doors) There now, we are quite safe. (sits down.) aye?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Aye?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: What the devil do you fit gaping! why don't you out with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Why do you sit staring and stretch∣ing your neck? why don't you tell it at once?

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: You sent for me down about your business—and, zounds! what is it? that I may go about mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: I send for you! you came here to tell me of something of great importance—tell it, and shorten your visit, when you please, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Sir, your ill manners, in your own house, are equal to your impudence in bringing me into it for nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Impudence, you vulgar man! it's well you are in my house, or, by the hand of this body, I'd have you pitched out of window.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Pitch me, you hard-headed old fool! if Torrendel was to behave so, I'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: I shall choak.— (rings) You're un∣der my roof, you pleb—so say what you will— Robin Hoofs!

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Damn your hoofs, and your horns, Sir! I can quit your house myself. You're as impudent as Torrendel.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter FANNY, crying, with Augusta's hat.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P:
Oh George! George! my Governess has run away with George! false fellow! to
dress himself up as the new postillion, and drive off with my Governess, when I only turned to fetch her hat and cloak.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: My son drive off with Augusta! Huzza! he's a dasher.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: And then Lord Torrendel's valet, to jump up behind the chaise—'twas all a packd thing to deceive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: What! zounds! the Frenchman gone off with my ward.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, they'll surely be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: What, the Frenchman?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: No! George! (peevish) Did I know where, i'd stand up in the church, and forbid the banns.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: But where are they gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Rattled down the beach, towards Sandgate Island.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Zounds! Robin Hoofs, John, the devil, I've lost my ward.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, I heard Sir Hans brought her down here to marry George; a demure look∣ing thing, she new better than to take the mad Lord, and I, myself to introduce her to my George; this is female friendship indeed, here's my friend's hat, and my friend's rib∣bands, oh that I had herself here.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III; and last.—Sandgate Istland; one shattered house, and a few wretched cottages.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P:
Damn the ferryman, not to run his boat boldly in the creek—oblige me to dash
through the water! If I could but get over to the continent, I'd fight like a true volunteer—the first Ensign that dropt, pick up his colours— huzza! I wish I had a sew shillings, to pay my passage in some fishing smack.

DIV3.P: There again—by heavens! you sha'n't have all the bailiff-work to yourself—we'll have a tussle for it—if you are stronger, I go—if not, I com∣mit your body to master shark—begone, or into this sea I dash you.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Then, there Sir, is a three hun∣dred pound Bank of England note—now I've at last done my job.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur. (picking it up)
SP.P: It is—and I to mistake my bright angel for the blackest of all imps, a catchpole! three hundred! now they shall see who is Lord Arthur D'Aumerle—who from? my kind father, doubtless. Now I've cash, where is my poor faithful Timolin.

DIV3.P: A dreary Island, but one house—you live yon∣der, master.

SP.SPEAKER: Robinson.
SP.P: Live! ah, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Ar.
SP.P:
Complain! Why, in the winter here, you've storms in high perfection—snow, hail, rain, lightning and thunder, neat as imported —no door to your house, and scarce a house to your door! the spangled canopy your bed-tes∣ters, and for a clear prospect no glass to your windows! not a tree on your island, because you wou'd not harbour noisy rooks to discompose
your slumbers!—nor even a bush! but that's vanity—that you might have it to say, you challenge the globe round to shew a spot more desolate.

SP.SPEAKER: Robinson.
SP.P: Why, sir, but for the charity of Mr. George Burgess we should be worse. He has unpeopled our island tho', and settled them com∣fortably near his father's. Since Lord Torren∣del, our landlord, leaves us to his Frenchman and that Master Dickins, I wish they'd take the house off my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Ar.
SP.P: They'll be taking it presently from about your ears— (aside.) Ha! ha! ha! I'm tickled with a strange ambition—I'll be king of this Island from my father's sole inheritance. Old Crusoe, I'll enchant your house from the court of poverty, to the castle of comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Robinson.
SP.P: You look comfort in you happy face. Welcome, sir, Dame!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Ar.
SP.P: This island is now my territory— here am I king! oh! for my queen! but plague of my palace.

SP.SPEAKER: L'oeil.
SP.P: Now dat your comrade has brought lady over in toder boat, let no one else cross but Milor. (Exit Boatman.) Ah! quel bonheur to find Augusta myself! now Monsieur Thomas and dat villain Irish thief may hunt her for deir own recreation—la voice—dis solitary isle—here milor have no person to interrupt.—

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.P:
The desire of seeing my cousin Arthur once again, before it is too late, can scarcely
reconcile me to this step—altogether this island wears a most forbidding aspect—I'll return, and sit in the chaise, till Fanny comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Loeil.
SP.P: Ah! ma chere (preventing her.) You must vait for Milor.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.P: He here! heavens! I'm betrayed—I see my folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Loeillet.
SP.P: I was your laquais, mon ange, and did sit behind de chaise, and you did not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.P: Pray, sir, suffer me to go.

SP.SPEAKER: Loeil.
SP.P: Oui, to Londres! dere Milor vill buy you fine cloaths and jewels, and you vill shine at operas and ball and concert, and he will kiss your hand dus.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Ar.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: L'oeil.
SP.P: Diantre!
SP.STAGE: (runs off. Lord Arthur pur∣sues. A plunge, as if in water, is heard.)

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.P: Heavens! sir, what have you done?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Ar.
SP.P: Only cast my bait into the sea— Lucifer will always bite at a scoundrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.P: Sir, he'll be drowned.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Ar.
SP.P: A souse, madam! he's already a pickled dog—don't be alarm'd—you're safe now from even the shadow of insult. How came you here in this remote place with that scoundrel? speak—but no matter—you seem distress'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug. (aside.)
SP.P: Vice should not humble the father in the opinion of the son.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Ar.
SP.P: Lean upon me, ma'am—holloo! old Crusoe, where's your dame? come, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Should Loeillet get my Augusta safe, here is no accommodation; I thought I had some tenants on this island! they've let the place run strangely to ruin. Confusion! Sir Hans!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir HANS, DICKINS, GEORGE and ROBIN, with postillions dress in hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: But dem it squire, why disguise yourself; sure you coud'n't be a confederate with that French pandar, to steal my daughter's gover∣ness?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Aye, George, where was the necessity of using artifice, to run away with Augusta, the very girl I wanted to give you.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Then to explain the mystery—some base designs of others, have sunk me into a schemer of stratagems. My lord, my name is Burgess.—I'm no profess'd knight-errant, yet I openly avow that I will endeavour henceforth to protect female innocence from your lordship's dishonourable purposes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H.
SP.P: Bravo! George. He has been drinking hock wich Lord Arthur.—My lord, I'll talk to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: My lord, to you I'll talk.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Then no shelter from open shame, but to turn champion myself! besides, the storm once blown over, my seeming her protector wins her love by gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Oh, my lord, here flies the sweet creature, with her character under her arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: That villain, Loeillet, make my son's servant a party in this business.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady TORRENDEL, veiled, and THOMAS.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Where's my guardian? how!

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Aye, I told you, but you wou'd run head∣long the devil. And there he stands, ready to receive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: What's your purpose, you scoun∣drels, in bringing the lady to this lonely place?

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Our purpose! well, that's very high!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Madam, rely upon my protection. I am bound by honour to defend you from every insult.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Certainly, my lord! every gentle∣man should be the protector of his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Lady Torrendel! damnation!

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: The Lady herself! then 'twas to her husband she was running, oh! here's a wonder, and a blunder!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P:
My Lord, I see you are confounded, yet could I hope your present humiliation pro∣ceeded from a sorrow that promised repentance, and consequent reformation, my heart's feelings for the man I did love and honor, should melt me to compassion! (weeps) but no! my lord! take
my resentment! my deserved, and bitter re∣proach! grief cannot reach a breast so callous as yours! it is only the stings of a wounded pride, and disappointed purpose, that now agitates you; reflect! return an humble gratitude to heaven for having made my unexpected arrival here the means of snatching you from the repetition of a crime the most hostile to society. A selfish, transient gratification, that must banish for ever an unhappy female from the paths of honor! shun'd thro' life by the best part of her own sex! —and even despised by you! the author of her shame! your wrongs to me are nothing, but your meditated shifts, tricks, and plans, which you call gallantries, reflect only a disgrace on the dignity of manhood!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Lady Torrendel—I confess I'm al∣together somewhat shocked, and wish—I say —I'm very unhappy to see—that is—I'm un∣happy at your suspecting—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Oh, you mistake, my lord! I have no suspicions! mine are all certainties—but even if you consider my throwing the past into the shade of oblivion, any indulgence, I shall insist upon a few conditions, and the first—turn your countenance and protection to that poor deserted youth! you are, as a parent, responsible for every violation that your neglect has occasioned him to make on the laws of propriety; if you refuse, I will be his parent, and I henceforth re∣gard your poor friendless son, with all the care and tenderness of maternal affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: He too, a witness!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Huzza, the joy that laughs on me, shall smile on all around; sir, I thank you for your bounty, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: My lady, I gave Lord Arthur the money, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: Well! well!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: How! from you, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Did you give countenance and relief, where wives, in general, look with con∣tempt and even hatred. Madam, can you par∣don?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Tor.
SP.P: My lord, your conduct renders you rather an object of pity, than resentment—you have implicitly delivered up your fortune, your character, nay more, my lord, your honor, to be the sport and property of an infamous parasite— your confidential savourite, your French Valet, has counteracted the rectitude of your intentions, by embezzelling the sums he had for purposes dictated by duty and nature. O! why will those who possess the godlike power of doing good, delegate a base, unworthy agent, for the kind purposes of soft humanity.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Then, madam, 'twas you that relieved me. You're an angel—angel you shall see! where's my divine Augusta?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir HANS, DICKINS, GEORGE, AUGUSTA, and TIMOLIN.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Here, boy, take Augusta,

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur. (advancing.)
SP.P: Thank ye, Sir Hans!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Thank ye, indeed, for that! George, devils in you! will you lose your wife so?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I've one ready at hand—father, with your leave and her own consent.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter FANNY, TIMOLIN sneaks in at the back.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: To be sure, I consent—and we all consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Oh! yes! we all consent—my dear governess, are you going to be married? It seems I'm going to be married. He! he! he! eh! George?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: To see my son taken before my face with an, he! he! he! s'blood, sir! let the girl go, he, he, he, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: Then I discover your tricks, sir, oh! oh! oh! indeed!—madam, no matter what he says—you are still heiress to your uncle Woodbine's fortune. Throw it into my bank, chuse me your guardian, I'll recover—dem'me, I'll send Sir Nob a sheet of cracklin ramskin, that shall reach from Chancery-lane, to the "devil and bag of nails, at Chelsea."

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: Can this be!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Indeed! well, even so the property of the mother should devolve to the son, to him I resign it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: No! sooner than take it from you, my generous cousin, Timolin and I will buffet the world again—where are you, old Bagatrot Casile?

SP.SPEAKER: Timclin.
SP.P: I'm here, your honour, dead or alive—we'll jump into our boots, before they're bought—and pull justice's wigs about—away, master! I'm your man thro' thick and thin, fire and smoke.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: I could force myself to accept this fortune—that is, with a certain sweet'ner,— Will you, my Augusta, accompany it?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Then, sir, for paltry gold, you'd quit your love! oh! fie!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Devil's in you, child! I was only joking about the girl over the hock, to make you marry George.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Tor.
SP.P: Why, this is right. Lady Tor∣rendel, your unexampled liberality will reclaim me into a husband and a father—my boy, were blessings mine, you should have one from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Timolin.
SP.P: Then, as you're not worth a blessing, show'r a bundle of yellow-boys upon us both.

SP.SPEAKER: Dickins.
SP.P: A good motion throw them into my bank.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: My lord, father, and you most adored Augusta, if I am destined to affluence, here is my model, (to George.) who can forego the comforts of life to bestow its necessaries on the indigent!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hans.
SP.P: Why, zounds! my most magnifi∣cent, gay Arthur, I thought you was to be George's model, and that he'd have grace enough like you to play the devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Arthur.
SP.P: So he shall—we'll kick Care out of the window, our abode shall be the House of Joy, and the first card of invitation shall be, to the Man of Sorrow.

Q.L: My faults how great! but as no fost'ring care
Did ever smile upon misfortune's heir!
The outcast oh receive! your pardon give,
And in your favour, let him happy live!

7. SPRIGS OF LAUREL, a Comic Opera in two Acts; by Mr. O'KEEFFEE. Price 1s.

10. The MIDNIGHT WANDERERS, a Comic Opera in two Acts; by Mr. Pearce. Price 1s.

12. WINDSOR CASTLE, an Opera, performed in honor of the Marriage of His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, by Mr. Pearce. With an elegant Vignette. Price 1s. 6d.
13. THE MAID of NORMANDY; or, The DEATH of the QUEEN of FRANCE: A Tragedy; by Mr. EYRE, late of Pembroke College, Cambridge. Price 1s. 6d.
14. CONSEQUENCES; or THE SCHOOL FOR PREJU∣DICE, A comedy, by Mr. EYRE. Price 1s. 6d.
15. THE TOWN BEFORE YOU, a Comedy; by Mrs. Cowley. Price 2s.
16. THE MYSTERIES OF THE CASTLE, an Opera; by Mr. P. Andrews. Price 2s.
17. ENGLAND PRESERVED, a Tragedy; by Mr. Watson, Price 2s.
